content:
Good problem. A couple of lingering thoughts:

- This has been said, but the stub generator should automatically split the lines into integers for the player.
- Your constraints indicate that the values of x, y, w, and h can be as high as 99, but the test cases go nowhere near that large. IMO there's no reason to have this problem so limited: make some test cases with explosive values! How about numbers up to 50,000? Or a million? :)
- C# comes with a Rectangle class that does the math of this problem for you.
the only odd thing is the stub generator. So, if you change it I'll approve your clash.

Nice idea.
Note that the area can be computed as the sum of both areas minus the area of the intersection and that the intersection is the rectangle [ max(x1,x2), min(x1+w1,x2+w2) [ x [the same for y[ (where [a,b[ is {a,a+1,...,b-1} if a<b and the empty set otherwise). Hence there is a O(1) formula (instead of your O(n^2) solution).

Please pay attention to spelling and grammar.

wantS
needS
neCeSSary

Is the wall infinite?

Also, I'm not sure about your solution. To me, the puzzle is adding two rectangle surfaces and possibly removing a third one (with an if).
the stub gÃ©nerator is pretty strange arent you suposed to define all of the variable separatly?

actually you are painting 2 rectangle if the rectangle overlap you wouldn't paint 2 time the same spot i've verified it and it's true that his solution is overcomplicated (you dont need a grid) but it's a way to work things out.

Thank you for the comment!

- I have corrected the stub generator
- I have added a test case with larger rectangles
- My idea for this clash is people can solve it in different ways, no matter how efficient it is the code.
The stub generator has the user reading 2 strings. But really what you want is for them to read 8 separate numbers. You should use the loopline command to reflect this.
